enRaw: The alleged conspiracy of the English Earl of Essex is uncovered. He loses his head in the Tower of London.$(Z)Rumor has it that Essex was executed because he patronized William Shakespeare. The actor and poet, born in Stratford in 1564, had staged the plays "Richard II" and "Julius Caesar" in his London Globe Theatre since 1595. The latter play was alleged by some of Elizabeth I's advisors to be part of a conspiracy in which Essex was supposedly involved, aimed at the deposition of the queen.$(N)

enRaw: On March 24, 1603, Queen Elizabeth I of England dies—broken. The last years since the death of her beloved Earl of Essex had become a torment to her. The new sovereign of England is now James I, son of Mary Stuart of Scotland. James I had already held the Scottish throne since 1567, at just one year old.$(Z)In Canada, the first French settlements are founded.$(N)

enRaw: In the year 1606, the situation escalates: In the Protestant imperial city of Donauwörth, there is a disturbance of a Catholic procession. Emperor Rudolf II then declares the city under ban and has it occupied by Maximilian of Bavaria's troops. A storm of indignation rises in the Protestant camp!$(Z)In the fight against the Protestants, the emperor's cousin Archduke Ferdinand of Styria and Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria now take the lead. In a secret agreement, Matthias, the emperor's brother, is appointed as the new head of the family due to Rudolf's inability. This is done without Emperor Rudolf's knowledge...$(Z)The Protestant-raised Albrecht Wallenstein converts to Catholicism.$(Z)In Leiden, the Dutch painter Rembrandt is born.$(Z)Spain collapses in a fourth state bankruptcy. This economic catastrophe fatally strikes the Fuggers of Augsburg with over three million ducats: The dynasty of the Fugger banking house seems to be definitively at its end!$(Z)Seemingly, for you have not invested in Spain like your relatives...$(N)
en: In the year 1606, the situation escalates: In the Protestant imperial city of Donauwörth, there is a disturbance of a Catholic procession. A storm of indignation rises in the Protestant camp!$ZIn the fight against the Protestants, the emperor's cousin Archduke Ferdinand of Styria and Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria now take the lead. In a secret agreement, Matthias, the emperor's brother, is appointed as the new head of the family due to Rudolf's inability. This is done without Emperor Rudolf's knowledge...$ZThe Protestant-raised Albrecht Wallenstein converts to Catholicism.$ZIn Leiden, the Dutch painter Rembrandt is born.$ZSpain collapses in a fourth state bankruptcy. This economic catastrophe fatally strikes the Fuggers of Augsburg with over three million ducats: The dynasty of the Fugger banking house seems to be definitively at its end!$ZSeemingly, for you have not invested in Spain like your relatives...$N

enRaw: France is encircled by Spain and Habsburg in 1607. In Paris, there is discussion about which side the country should take in the conflict between Catholics and Protestants. The Jesuits have great influence, and their papal special envoy Antonio Possevino urges Henry IV to side against the Protestants.$(Z)Among the people, the Jesuits are not popular due to rumors that they were connected to the assassination of Henry III in 1589.$(Z)In this very year, a publication by the Spanish Jesuit Mariana appeared, in which he took a stance on royal power and wrote that the people have the right to kill an unjust ruler. Mariana mentioned in this context a certain Clement, who was considered an ornament of France.$(Z)However, this very Clement was the murderer of Henry III...$(N)
en: France is encircled by Spain and Habsburg in 1607. In Paris, there is discussion about which side the country should take in the conflict between Catholics and Protestants. The Jesuits have great influence, and their papal special envoy Antonio Possevino urges Henry IV to side against the Protestants.$ZAmong the people, the Jesuits are not popular due to rumors that they were connected to the assassination of Henry III in 1589.$ZIn this very year, a publication by the Spanish Jesuit Mariana appeared, in which he took a stance on royal power and wrote that the people have the right to kill an unjust ruler. Mariana mentioned in this context a certain Clement, who was considered an ornament of France.$ZHowever, this very Clement was the murderer of Henry III...$N

Die Mn~ner um Possevino sehen den Schlssel zur Restaura~tion der alten Ord~nung im deutschen Reich und ver~suchen, Hein~rich dazu zu be~wegen, sich gegen die Pro~testan~ten zu stel~len. string: Der Reli~gions~streit zwi~schen Pro~testan~ten und Katho~li~ken ver~schärft sich. Auch ver~mehren sich poli~ti~sche Kon~flikte unter den Reichs~ständen. enRaw: The religious conflict between Protestants and Catholics intensifies. Political conflicts among the Imperial Estates also increase. This leads to the founding of the Protestant Union on May 14, 1608, in Auhausen. To defend against "illegalities," the Electoral Palatinate, Anhalt, Württemberg, Baden-Ansbach, and several other principalities join forces.$(Z)Forced by the pressure of his brothers and cousins, Emperor Rudolf resigns in favor of his brother Matthias over Austria and Hungary. Practically, he only rules over Bohemia.$(Z)Henry IV of France, having himself converted to Catholicism, comes increasingly under the influence of the Jesuits. The men around Possevino see the key to the restoration of the old order in the German Empire and try to persuade Henry to side against the Protestants. The French state government around the Calvinist finance minister Sully seems powerless...$(Z)The Duke of Richelieu, Armand-Jean du Plessis, is appointed Bishop of Luçon.$(N)

enRaw: The death of the childless Duke of Jülich, Cleves, and Berg threatens to invoke a war: Catholics and Protestants reach for the landless territories on the Lower Rhine.$(Z)The High Church England intervenes on the side of the Protestants. Spain, exhausted after the truce with the Netherlands, sides with the Catholics.$(Z)Germany looks to France: King Henry IV's decision will give one side the necessary superiority to begin a war.$(Z)On July 9, 1609, Emperor Rudolf II issues the Letter of Majesty for Bohemia. In it, he grants the predominantly evangelical Bohemian Estates religious freedom and other privileges. He thereby secures the support of the estates against his brother Matthias, to whom he had lost Hungary and Austria a year earlier.$(Z)To preserve the land peace and the Catholic religion, the Catholic League is subsequently founded:$(Z)Under the leadership of Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria, all the larger Catholic Imperial Estates, except the Emperor and the city of Salzburg, unite.$(Z)In Italy, Galileo Galilei invents his own astronomical telescope, modeled after the first telescope constructed in Holland.$(N)

Spain, exhausted after the truce with the Netherlands, sides with the Catholics.$ZGermany looks to France: King Henry IV's decision will give one side the necessary superiority to begin a war.$ZOn July 9, 1609, Emperor Rudolf II issues the Letter of Majesty for Bohemia. In it, he grants the predominantly evangelical Bohemian Estates religious freedom and other privileges. He thereby secures the support of the estates against his brother Matthias, to whom he had lost Hungary and Austria a year earlier.$ZTo preserve the land peace and the Catholic religion, the Catholic League is subsequently founded:$ZUnder the leadership of Duke Maximilian I of Bavaria, all the larger Catholic Imperial Estates, except the Emperor and the city of Salzburg, unite.$ZIn Italy, Galileo Galilei invents his own astronomical telescope, modeled after the first telescope constructed in Holland.$N

Mai 1610 fest~gelegt.$ZAls am Abend des 14. Mai die knig~liche Kutsche durch die Gas~sen von Paris rollt, gert der Knig in einen Hin~terhalt und wird er~mordet. enRaw: In Germany, additional territories join the Protestant Union: Brandenburg, Hesse-Kassel, Ulm, Strasbourg, and Nuremberg.$(Z)Henry IV of France has finally made a decision: Despite his Catholic faith, he wants to side with the German Protestants. After consultations with Finance Minister Sully, he has concluded that France must break free from the grip of Spain and Habsburg. The departure for the army is set for May 18, 1610.$(Z)When the royal carriage rolls through the streets of Paris on the evening of May 14, the king falls into an ambush and is murdered. The arrested perpetrator, Ravaillac, is a rough character of fanatical zeal. Interrogated under torture about his accomplices, he merely confesses that he committed the act because the king was about to wage war against the Catholic Church. The investigations reveal that the murderer had made terrible hints to a Jesuit priest. However, the priest had not taken the perpetrator seriously...$(Z)A wave of Jesuit agitation sweeps through the populace, spurred on by the parliament and the university. Since Louis XIII is only nine years old, France is without a head at a crucial moment in its history, and the regency is taken over by the infant's mother, Marie de’ Medici.$(Z)Galileo Galilei becomes a court mathematician in Florence and publicly advocates the Copernican model of the universe, which no longer assigns the Earth as the center of the solar system.$(N)

The departure for the army is set for May 18, 1610.$ZWhen the royal carriage rolls through the streets of Paris on the evening of May 14, the king falls into an ambush and is murdered. The arrested perpetrator, Ravaillac, is a rough character of fanatical zeal. Interrogated under torture about his accomplices, he merely confesses that he committed the act because the king was about to wage war against the Catholic Church. The investigations reveal that the murderer had made terrible hints to a Jesuit priest. However, the priest had not taken the perpetrator seriously...$ZA wave of Jesuit agitation sweeps through the populace, spurred on by the parliament and the university. Since Louis XIII is only nine years old, France is without a head at a crucial moment in its history, and the regency is taken over by the infant's mother, Marie de’ Medici.$ZGalileo Galilei becomes a court mathematician in Florence and publicly advocates the Copernican model of the universe, which no longer assigns the Earth as the center of the solar system.$N

Im heimat~lichen Ordens~haus stirbt er 1611 an den fol~gen sei~ner Krank~heit.$ZIm Hause ster~reich wird der Zwist zwi~schen den frst~lichen Brdern offen~bar: Der un~tti~ge Kai~ser Rudolf wird durch die Erz~herzge ab~ge~setzt. Sein Herr~schafts~ge~biet er~streckt sich nur noch auf das Ge~biet di~rekt um Prag.$ZEs wird ge~munkelt, daá Rudolfs Bru~der Mat~thias die Ab~sicht habe, den Steirer~herzog Ferdi~nand, der als Jesui~tenfreu~nd gilt, zum neuen Knig von Bh~men zu machen...$ZDer kai~serliche Hof~astro~nom Kepler ver~bessert sein Fern~rohr. Der Kai~ser schul~det ihm trotz sei~ner Ver~dienste mo~na~telang den Lohn, so daá Kepler, des~sen Frau und Kind ge~storben sind, Prag bitter~arm gen ster~reich ver~lát. Die evange~lisch ge~sinnten Land~stnde von Ober~ster~reich geben ihm ein Amt als Land~schafts~mathe~mati~kus und ber~tragen ihm in Linz die Re~vision der ober~ster~reichischen Land~karten.$N
string: Auf der Heim~reise von Prag nach Ferrara er~krankt Antonio Possevino. Im heimat~lichen Ordens~haus stirbt er 1611 an den fol~gen sei~ner Krank~heit.$ZIm Hause Öster~reich wird der Zwist zwi~schen den fürst~lichen Brüdern offen~bar: Der un~täti~ge Kai~ser Rudolf wird durch die Erz~herzöge ab~ge~setzt. Sein Herr~schafts~ge~biet er~streckt sich nur noch auf das Ge~biet di~rekt um Prag.$ZEs wird ge~munkelt, daß Rudolfs Bru~der Mat~thias die Ab~sicht habe, den Steirer~herzog Ferdi~nand, der als Jesui~tenfreu~nd gilt, zum neuen König von Böh~men zu machen...$ZDer kai~serliche Hof~astro~nom Kepler ver~bessert sein Fern~rohr. enRaw: On the journey home from Prague to Ferrara, Antonio Possevino falls ill. In the home Order's house, he dies in 1611 from the consequences of his illness.$(Z)In the House of Austria, the discord between the princely brothers becomes apparent: The inactive Emperor Rudolf is deposed by the archdukes. His domain is now only the area directly around Prague.$(Z)It is rumored that Rudolf's brother Matthias intends to make the Styrian Duke Ferdinand, who is considered a friend of the Jesuits, the new King of Bohemia...$(Z)The imperial court astronomer Kepler improves his telescope. Despite his merits, the Emperor owes him wages for months, so Kepler, whose wife and child have died, leaves Prague bitter and destitute for Austria. The Protestant-minded estates of Upper Austria offer him a position as a regional mathematician and task him with revising the maps of Upper Austria in Linz.$(N)

enRaw: The Netherlands join the Protestant Union.$(Z)In England, discontent with James I is growing louder. The king is a supporter of the Church of England, while large parts of the population are influenced by stricter Old Testamentarian currents of the Reformation. These Puritans subject the king to sharp, relentless criticism.$(Z)Parliament denies approval of James's excessive tax demands to finance expensive castle constructions and an extravagant life at court. Slowly but surely, the government is slipping into the hands of favorites...$(N)

enRaw: The Dutch occupy the Portuguese spice islands, they now also cruise in the East Indian waters and expand their trade as far as Japan. From China, the first ships loaded to the brim with tea reach European ports.$(Z)In Spain, a large war fleet is being equipped in all ports. enRaw: Ferdinand II receives the Hungarian crown.$(Z)In Prague, the resistance of Bohemian Protestants against the Emperor's restorative measures erupts. On May 23, 1618, during a diet in Prague, the hated imperial governors Martinic and Slawata are thrown out of the windows of the Hradčany according to old Hussite custom.$(Z)The Defenestration of Prague initiates the Bohemian revolt. This marks the beginning of the Thirty Years' War...$(Z)Albrecht Wallenstein sides with the Emperor.$(Z)Through the efforts of the Duke of Luynes, Richelieu is recalled to the French court.$(N)

enRaw: On March 20, 1619, the German Emperor Matthias dies. His successor becomes Ferdinand II.$(Z)Nevertheless, the Bohemian estates depose Ferdinand II as King of Bohemia.$(Z)In August 1619, the Protestant estates elect Elector Frederick V of the Palatinate, the leader of the Protestant Union, as Frederick I, the new King of Bohemia. This causes the Bohemian revolt to spread throughout the entire empire.$(Z)The Catholic League assembly in Würzburg decides to set up an army under Johann Tilly. In the first years of the Thirty Years' War, Ferdinand II's imperial power will rely on this.$(N)
en: On March 20, 1619, the German Emperor Matthias dies. His successor becomes Ferdinand II.$ZNevertheless, the Bohemian estates depose Ferdinand II as King of Bohemia.$ZIn August 1619, the Protestant estates elect Elector Frederick V of the Palatinate, the leader of the Protestant Union, as Frederick I, the new King of Bohemia. This causes the Bohemian revolt to spread throughout the entire empire.$ZThe Catholic League assembly in Würzburg decides to set up an army under Johann Tilly. In the first years of the Thirty Years' War, Ferdinand II's imperial power will rely on this.$N

enRaw: The Battle of August 6, 1623, at Stadtlohn ends the Bohemian-Palatine War. Frederick IV of the Palatinate is ultimately defeated by the Catholic troops under Johann Tilly, and the Palatine electoral dignity falls to Bavaria. There and in Austria, a massive suppression of Protestantism begins.$(Z)Halberstadt, Hildesheim, Minden, and Osnabrück are re-Catholicized under Tilly.$(Z)Rembrandt becomes a student of Pieter Lastman in Amsterdam; however, he initially continues to focus his work on his birthplace, Leiden.$(N)

enRaw: In northern Germany, attempts at re-Catholicization by the Habsburgs prompt Christian IV of Denmark to intervene in the military actions. He allies with the estates of the Lower Saxon Circle, the Dutch Republic, and England.$(Z)Albrecht Wallenstein is granted the title of Duke of Friedland. Wallenstein offers to Emperor Ferdinand II to raise an army against the Protestants at his own expense.$(Z)Richelieu supports the Grisons in their fight against imperial Habsburg.$(Z)On March 27, 1625, the English King James I dies in Hertford. His son, Charles I, becomes the new King of England.$(N)

Wallenstein offers to Emperor Ferdinand II to raise an army against the Protestants at his own expense.$ZRichelieu supports the Grisons in their fight against imperial Habsburg.$ZOn March 27, 1625, the English King James I dies in Hertford. His son, Charles I, becomes the new King of England.$N

In August of the same year, the Danish King Christian IV is defeated at Lutter am Barenberge by the Catholics under Johann Tilly.$(N)

enRaw: After the occupation of the Baltic Sea coast, Christian IV must conclude the Peace of Lübeck on May 12, 1629. This peace and the victories of Johann Tilly and Albrecht Wallenstein enable Emperor Ferdinand II's Edict of Restitution on March 6, 1629: All church properties confiscated by Protestants since the Treaty of Passau in 1552 are to be returned to the Catholics. The Reformed are to be excluded from the Peace of Religion. The Catholic estates of the empire are allowed to re-Catholicize their subjects. This threatens the extinction of Protestantism in Germany.$(Z)After increasing protests against his policies, Charles I dissolves the English Parliament.$(N)
en: After the occupation of the Baltic Sea coast, Christian IV must conclude the Peace of Lübeck on May 12, 1629. This peace and the victories of Johann Tilly and Albrecht Wallenstein enable Emperor Ferdinand II's Edict of Restitution on March 6, 1629: All church properties confiscated by Protestants since the Treaty of Passau in 1552 are to be returned to the Catholics. The Reformed are to be excluded from the Peace of Religion. The Catholic estates of the empire are allowed to re-Catholicize their subjects. This threatens the extinction of Protestantism in Germany.$ZAfter increasing protests against his policies, Charles I dissolves the English Parliament.$N

enRaw: At the Electoral Diet in Regensburg, the princes complain about the brutal excesses of Wallenstein's soldiery and the general's arrogance. Emperor Ferdinand gives in to his princes' demands and dismisses his general. At the same time, the troops of the Protestant Swedish King Gustavus Adolphus land in Pomerania.$(Z)Wallenstein's palace in Prague is completed and named "Waldstein Palace."$(Z)Johann Tilly succeeds Albrecht Wallenstein as Generalissimo of the imperial troops.$(Z)The papal diplomat Jules Mazarin and Cardinal Richelieu meet in Lyon. Henceforth, Mazarin campaigns for Richelieu's policy at the Curia.$(Z)On November 15, Johannes Kepler dies in Regensburg.$(N)

enRaw: In January 1631, France and Sweden agree in the Treaty of Bärwalde that the French will henceforth financially support the Protestant Swedes to counter the danger of an overly powerful empire.$(Z)Johann Tilly's troops stand before Magdeburg. On May 20, 1631, the city falls and is completely destroyed. In September, Gustavus Adolphus succeeds in defeating Tilly's forces at Breitenfeld with Saxon help.$(Z)Due to the dramatic situation, the emperor recalls Wallenstein.$(Z)Rembrandt relocates to Amsterdam and begins his second creative period.$(N)

enRaw: In the spring of 1632, the troops of the Swedish king advance from Mainz into southern Germany and capture Augsburg and Munich. After the Battle of Rain am Lech, the imperial lieutenant general Johann Tilly dies on April 15, 1632, in Ingolstadt.$(Z)Albrecht Wallenstein is subsequently entrusted by Emperor Ferdinand II with almost unlimited powers and throws his standing army against Gustavus Adolphus. In the Battle of Lützen, the Swedish king dies in November 1632.$(Z)Galileo Galilei once again comes into conflict with the Catholic Church after he has clearly supported Copernicus's teaching in his "Dialogo," published in Florence, stating that the Earth is not the center of the solar system.$(N)

enRaw: The leader of Swedish politics, Axel Oxenstierna, consolidates the southern German circles into the Protestant Heilbronn League. Albrecht Wallenstein independently conducts negotiations with the Swedes and therefore falls out of favor with the emperor.$(Z)The Catholic Church initiates a trial against Galileo Galilei. Threatened with death, he recants his teachings and is sentenced on June 22, 1633, to indefinite imprisonment, which he is allowed to serve at his country house near Florence. In connection with the trial, Galileo Galilei is attributed with the phrase "And yet it (the Earth) moves."$(N)

enRaw: The Thirty Years' War comes to an end with the Peace of Westphalia. In Münster, peace treaties between the Emperor and France are drawn up, and in Osnabrück between the Emperor and Sweden. The Peace of Augsburg of 1555 is confirmed, and the Calvinists are recognized as the third religion. Furthermore, the state religion follows the principle of "Cuius regio, eius religio": The ruler determines the state religion.$(Z)France is granted possession of numerous cities, receiving the landgraveships of Upper and Lower Alsace from Habsburg as well as jurisdiction over ten Alsatian imperial cities.$(Z)Sweden gains possession of Western Pomerania, several Baltic Sea islands, the Bishopric of Verden, and the Archbishopric of Bremen.$(Z)Frederick William of Brandenburg obtains through skillful maneuvering Hinterpommern, Minden, Halberstadt, as well as the expectation of Magdeburg.$(Z)The imperial estates receive full sovereignty over their lands, as well as the right to form alliances of any kind, unless they are directed against the Emperor or the Empire. Bavaria retains possession of the electoral title of the Palatinate gained in 1623, and a new German electoral title, the eighth, is created for the Palatinate.$(Z)In Paris, the first Fronde uprisings break out. The parliaments oppose the regent Anne and Cardinal Mazarin. There are barricade fights, and the court flees.$(Z)In Great Britain, Oliver Cromwell achieves a victory over the Scots at Preston. He excludes the Presbyterians from Parliament in favor of the Independents.$(N)

Furthermore, the state religion follows the principle of "Cuius regio, eius religio": The ruler determines the state religion.$ZFrance is granted possession of numerous cities, receiving the landgraveships of Upper and Lower Alsace from Habsburg as well as jurisdiction over ten Alsatian imperial cities.$ZSweden gains possession of Western Pomerania, several Baltic Sea islands, the Bishopric of Verden, and the Archbishopric of Bremen.$ZFrederick William of Brandenburg obtains through skillful maneuvering Hinterpommern, Minden, Halberstadt, as well as the expectation of Magdeburg.$ZThe imperial estates receive full sovereignty over their lands, as well as the right to form alliances of any kind, unless they are directed against the Emperor or the Empire. Bavaria retains possession of the electoral title of the Palatinate gained in 1623, and a new German electoral title, the eighth, is created for the Palatinate.$ZIn Paris, the first Fronde uprisings break out. The parliaments oppose the regent Anne and Cardinal Mazarin. There are barricade fights, and the court flees.$ZIn Great Britain, Oliver Cromwell achieves a victory over the Scots at Preston. He excludes the Presbyterians from Parliament in favor of the Independents.$N

enRaw: After the conclusion of peace, the full extent of the devastation becomes clear: The war, which raged over the lands of the Holy Roman Empire for 30 years, was actually a European one. All the major powers of the continent conducted their dealings and battles on German soil.$(Z)The country is bled dry. Forty percent of its wealth and an equally large part of the German population have been wiped out, territories are lost and the country is more than ever under the influence of foreign powers.$(Z)Supported by Spain, the Fronde of the Princes breaks out in France. The high nobility joins the parliaments and it leads to the capture of Paris.$(Z)The English King Charles I is executed on January 30, England is declared a Commonwealth by the Parliament. Cromwell becomes the head of the Council of State.$(N)

Charles II, the son of the executed English king living in France, lands in Scotland.$(N)

enRaw: The strength of the French insurgents is worn down by power struggles between the princes. The mood begins to shift in favor of Louis XIV. Nevertheless, Cardinal Mazarin is forced into exile by disparagements.$(Z)Charles II invades England from Scotland. On September 3, 1651, the Battle of Worcester occurs with Oliver Cromwell's troops. Charles II is defeated and must flee again.$(N)

enRaw: On April 2, 1657, Emperor Ferdinand III dies in Vienna. Leopold I of Austria becomes the German Emperor.$(Z)Due to the increase in Swedish power, Leopold I, Denmark, and Poland form an alliance. Brandenburg leaves the alliance with Sweden, concludes peace with Poland in Wehlau on September 19, and under Frederick William the Great, gains sovereignty in Prussia.$(Z)In England, Parliament offers Oliver Cromwell the crown. However, he declines and remains Lord Protector.$(N)
en: On April 2, 1657, Emperor Ferdinand III dies in Vienna. Leopold I of Austria becomes the German Emperor.$ZDue to the increase in Swedish power, Leopold I, Denmark, and Poland form an alliance. Brandenburg leaves the alliance with Sweden, concludes peace with Poland in Wehlau on September 19, and under Frederick William the Great, gains sovereignty in Prussia.$ZIn England, Parliament offers Oliver Cromwell the crown. However, he declines and remains Lord Protector.$N

enRaw: Moved by Habsburg diplomacy, Russia invades Swedish Livonia. Charles X Gustav is driven out of Poland and turns against Denmark. In the Peace of Roskilde, Sweden achieves the cession of Danish-occupied southern Sweden, Trondheim, and Bornholm.$(Z)Cardinal Mazarin and the Mainz Elector Johann Philipp von Schönborn establish the first Rhine Confederation. On August 15, 1658, the spiritual electors of Palatinate-Neuburg, Hesse-Kassel, Brunswick-Lüneburg, and Bremen-Verden unite with France for ten years. The Rhine Confederation subsequently becomes an instrument of French policy in Germany.$(Z)On September 3, the Lord Protector of the Commonwealth, Oliver Cromwell, dies in London.$(N)
en: Moved by Habsburg diplomacy, Russia invades Swedish Livonia. Charles X Gustav is driven out of Poland and turns against Denmark. In the Peace of Roskilde, Sweden achieves the cession of Danish-occupied southern Sweden, Trondheim, and Bornholm.$ZCardinal Mazarin and the Mainz Elector Johann Philipp von Schönborn establish the first Rhine Confederation. On August 15, 1658, the spiritual electors of Palatinate-Neuburg, Hesse-Kassel, Brunswick-Lüneburg, and Bremen-Verden unite with France for ten years. The Rhine Confederation subsequently becomes an instrument of French policy in Germany.$ZOn September 3, the Lord Protector of the Commonwealth, Oliver Cromwell, dies in London.$N

enRaw: On February 13, 1660, Charles X Gustav of Sweden dies in Gothenburg. Subsequently, the Peace of Oliva, driven by Cardinal Mazarin, England, and the Dutch States General, restores the balance of power in Northern Europe as it was in 1655. Only the sovereignty acquired by Prussia in 1657 is confirmed.$(Z)Together with the Peace of Westphalia, the Rhine Confederation, and the Treaty of the Pyrenees, the Peace of Oliva establishes French supremacy in Europe in the second half of the 17th century.$(Z)In England, during the Restoration of the Stuarts, Charles II ascends the throne: Without encountering significant resistance, General Monk marches from Scotland to London. There he convenes a new Parliament, which recalls the exiled son of Charles I to England and proclaims him the new king.$(N)
en: On February 13, 1660, Charles X Gustav of Sweden dies in Gothenburg. Subsequently, the Peace of Oliva, driven by Cardinal Mazarin, England, and the Dutch States General, restores the balance of power in Northern Europe as it was in 1655. Only the sovereignty acquired by Prussia in 1657 is confirmed.$ZTogether with the Peace of Westphalia, the Rhine Confederation, and the Treaty of the Pyrenees, the Peace of Oliva establishes French supremacy in Europe in the second half of the 17th century.$ZIn England, during the Restoration of the Stuarts, Charles II ascends the throne: Without encountering significant resistance, General Monk marches from Scotland to London. There he convenes a new Parliament, which recalls the exiled son of Charles I to England and proclaims him the new king.$N

string: Beim Rück~zug der französi~schen Trup~pen im Pfälzi~schen Erb~folgekrieg kommt es im gan~zen Rhein~tal, vor allem aber in Heidel~berg, zu großen Zer~störun~gen.$ZWil~helm III. und Maria II. In der Toleranz~akte wird den Non~kon~for~misten das Recht auf freie Reli~gionsaus~übung ge~währt.$N
enRaw: During the retreat of the French troops in the War of the Palatine Succession, there is great destruction throughout the Rhine Valley, especially in Heidelberg.$(Z) William III and Mary II Stuart jointly ascend the throne of Great Britain and Ireland. England and the Netherlands join the alliance against France.$(Z) In the *Declaration of Rights*, John Locke theoretically establishes the separation of powers into legislative and executive to ensure personal freedom and the protection of citizens' property.$(Z) The *Bill of Rights* provides the monarchy in England with a constitutionally defined basis as a parliamentary monarchy: Laws are only valid if both the Crown and Parliament approve them. Parliament receives the right to approve taxes; the sovereignty of Parliament over the Crown is definitively confirmed.$(Z) Catholics are excluded from the line of succession. The Toleration Act grants Nonconformists the right to free religious practice.$(N)
en: During the retreat of the French troops in the War of the Palatine Succession, there is great destruction throughout the Rhine Valley, especially in Heidelberg.$Z William III and Mary II Stuart jointly ascend the throne of Great Britain and Ireland. England and the Netherlands join the alliance against France.$Z In the *Declaration of Rights*, John Locke theoretically establishes the separation of powers into legislative and executive to ensure personal freedom and the protection of citizens' property.$Z The *Bill of Rights* provides the monarchy in England with a constitutionally defined basis as a parliamentary monarchy: Laws are only valid if both the Crown and Parliament approve them. Parliament receives the right to approve taxes; the sovereignty of Parliament over the Crown is definitively confirmed.$Z Catholics are excluded from the line of succession. The Toleration Act grants Nonconformists the right to free religious practice.$N

string: Nach kur~zer Zeit trifft die Stadt~garde in der Villa ein und man schickt einen Boten, um Euch als Zeu~gen be~fragen zu kön~nen. Als Ihr das Ge~bäude er~neut er~reicht, bit~tet Euch der Haupt~mann so~gleich in den Gar~ten hinaus. 'Ich habe mir sagen las~sen, daß Ihr über einen schar~fen Ver~stand ver~fügt. enRaw: After a short time, the city guard arrives at the villa, and a messenger is sent to question you as a witness. When you reach the building again, the captain immediately invites you out into the garden. 'I have been told that you possess a keen mind. Perhaps you can assist me in solving this heinous crime, after all, you were with the four suspects during the meal. The culprit must be found... string: Der Prie~ster packt seine Bücher zu~sammen, unter den An~wesen~den er~hebt sich ein un~zu~frie~de~nes Murren. >Ach, das wäre mir beinahe ent~fallen...< er~hebt sich die Stimme des Gottes~mannes noch ein~mal. >Ich habe hier für jeden An~wesen~den noch ein Kouvert, Ihr könnt es beim Hinaus~gehen mit~nehmen.< Mit ge~mischten Ge~fühlen nehmt Ihr den Brief an Euch und ver~laßt den Ort des Schreckens...$N$N

en: The priest packs his books together, among the attendees an unhappy murmur rises. >Ah, I almost forgot...< the voice of the man of God rises again. >I have an envelope here for each attendee; you can take it with you on your way out.< With mixed feelings, you take the letter and leave the place of horror...$N$N

enRaw: $(Z)You go to the neighboring table, introduce yourself, and ask if you may offer them a cool drink. The farmers initially look at you a bit suspiciously. But when they hear the word beer, they become more amiable, and before you know it, you’re sitting opposite them on a quickly fetched stool. After the innkeeper brings three new mugs and you've taken a deep draft, you start talking. One of the countrymen clears his throat, wipes the foam from his beard, and begins:$(N)'Well, noble %(s), it is like this. Actually, there's not much to say, but when we brought a cartload of grain to the market in Bergstedt a week ago, a man approached us...' The other farmer nods and draws thoughtfully on his pipe. 'He looked peculiar, had tousled hair, glasses, and was dressed entirely in black.'$(N)'Hmm...', the first continues. 'He asked if we would sell him all our grain, saying that he lived in a villa a few kilometers outside the city and only came down to the city rarely in the year. He then offered us a price we couldn't refuse: %(b) thaler! That's 3 thalers more than you can get for grain on the market this year. Well, we couldn't say no.' The man looks regretfully at his now empty mug. 'But that's not really important...' Do you want to bribe the man and $(Z)%(a)call the innkeeper again or%(a)think the same and leave?$|
en: $ZYou go to the neighboring table, introduce yourself, and ask if you may offer them a cool drink. The farmers initially look at you a bit suspiciously. But when they hear the word beer, they become more amiable, and before you know it, you’re sitting opposite them on a quickly fetched stool. After the innkeeper brings three new mugs and you've taken a deep draft, you start talking. One of the countrymen clears his throat, wipes the foam from his beard, and begins:$N'Well, noble %s, it is like this. Actually, there's not much to say, but when we brought a cartload of grain to the market in Bergstedt a week ago, a man approached us...' The other farmer nods and draws thoughtfully on his pipe. 'He looked peculiar, had tousled hair, glasses, and was dressed entirely in black.'$N'Hmm...', the first continues. 'He asked if we would sell him all our grain, saying that he lived in a villa a few kilometers outside the city and only came down to the city rarely in the year. He then offered us a price we couldn't refuse: %b thaler! That's 3 thalers more than you can get for grain on the market this year. Well, we couldn't say no.' The man looks regretfully at his now empty mug. 'But that's not really important...' Do you want to bribe the man and $Z%acall the innkeeper again or%athink the same and leave?$|

enRaw: $(Z)When you wave the innkeeper over again, the faces of your counterparts brighten. 'Well, when we arrived at the villa, we brought the grain into a large outbuilding. And in a hall there, a machine was hovering, like...' The farmer hesitates. '...like held in the air by magical forces. Witchcraft!' Both nod.$(N)'The white-haired man seemed annoyed and mentioned that he was an inventor, but quickly sent us away again. Well, what can I say, that wasn't right.' the farmer concludes his story. enRaw: The information provided by the two countrymen has proven to be correct: After leaving Bergstedt, you discover, after a few hours, the villa of the inventor built high on the rocks. At your knock, the door opens, and a man appears. You recount the encounter with the farmers, but the man dismisses them: 'Boorish peasants! Nothing but ignoramuses! Magic, as if I would laugh. Look, I am an inventor, and currently I am engaged in constructing means of transportation that... Let’s say, they have certain advantages compared to ordinary... carts, for example. Only,' he makes a disheartened face, 'I unfortunately have no more financial means.' Do you wish to$(Z)%(a)offer him your help%(a)or leave the man?$|

Hm, wenn Ihr mich sagen wir mit %d Ta~lern pro Jahr unter~stützen wür~det, dann werde ich Euch sicher in drei Jah~ren Er~geb~nis~se zei~gen...' Wollt Ihr$Z%aakzeptieren oder%asagen, daß Ihr das Geld nicht habt?$|
enRaw: $(Z)The man smiles happily. 'Oh, very nice.' After leading you into the library, he rummages for an old leather folder and opens it. You catch sight of strangely intriguing construction drawings.$(N)'I have dealt with various machines,' he begins. 'Here, a steam cart, and this here...' He flips through the folder. '...this is a submarine. Most advanced devices!' You skeptically make a face. The inventor is undeterred and says, 'I do not yet know which is the easiest to build. Hmm, if you were to support me with, say, %(d) thalers per year, then I would surely show you results in three years...' Do you wish to$(Z)%(a)accept or%(a)say that you don't have the money?$|

raw: $CIn Stcke ge~brochen liegt die alte Ein~heit Deutsch~lands. Die Kaiser~krone hat ihren Schim~mer ver~loren, die christ~liche Kirche ist in zwei feind~liche Lager zer~fallen und Haá und Bruder~kampf be~stimmen den Ab~lauf die~ses ent~fessel~ten Jahr~hunderts.$ZDie Her~ren die~ser neuen Zeit, die Knige und Frsten der National~staaten, er~heben sich strahlend, gleich dem Sonnen~knig, ber den von Armut & Not heim~ge~suchten Vlkern.$ZIm Jahr 1588 bezwingt Eng~land die mchtige spani~sche Armada. 1596 folgt der dritte spani~sche Staats~bankrott. Damit sind die be~rhmten deutschen Bank~huser der Fug~ger und Welser an~nhernd rui~niert.$ZDer Dreiáig~jhrige Krieg rast ber die Fluren Deutsch~lands und hin~terlát ein Chaos von un~vor~stell~barem Aus~maá. Sein Ende ist die Zer~schla~gung und die Ohn~macht des deutschen Reichs.$ZVon tiefer Unruhe ist die Mensch~heit er~faát, sie sucht nach neuen Wegen, um die Rtsel des Da~seins zu lsen. Wage~mutig und frei von den frommen Bindungen der Vter wirkt der Mensch forschend und wgend, erfindend und entdeckend. Es ist dies das Zeit~alter von Krieg, Philosophie und Naturwissenschaft.$Z$CUnd: Es ist dies die Zeit Eurer Rck~kehr, es ist das Zeit~alter von$ZFUG~GER II.$N$N$B
string: $CIn Stücke ge~brochen liegt die alte Ein~heit Deutsch~lands. Die Kaiser~krone hat ihren Schim~mer ver~loren, die christ~liche Kirche ist in zwei feind~liche Lager zer~fallen und Haß und Bruder~kampf be~stimmen den Ab~lauf die~ses ent~fessel~ten Jahr~hunderts.$ZDie Her~ren die~ser neuen Zeit, die Könige und Fürsten der National~staaten, er~heben sich strahlend, gleich dem Sonnen~könig, über den von Armut & Not heim~ge~suchten Völkern.$ZIm Jahr 1588 bezwingt Eng~land die mächtige spani~sche Armada. 1596 folgt der dritte spani~sche Staats~bankrott. Damit sind die be~rühmten deutschen Bank~häuser der Fug~ger und Welser an~nähernd rui~niert.$ZDer Dreißig~jährige Krieg rast über die Fluren Deutsch~lands und hin~terläßt ein Chaos von un~vor~stell~barem Aus~maß. Sein Ende ist die Zer~schla~gung und die Ohn~macht des deutschen Reichs.$ZVon tiefer Unruhe ist die Mensch~heit er~faßt, sie sucht nach neuen Wegen, um die Rätsel des Da~seins zu lösen. Wage~mutig und frei von den frommen Bindungen der Väter wirkt der Mensch forschend und wägend, erfindend und entdeckend. Es ist dies das Zeit~alter von Krieg, Philosophie und Naturwissenschaft.$Z$CUnd: Es ist dies die Zeit Eurer Rück~kehr, es ist das Zeit~alter von$ZFUG~GER II.$N$N$B
enRaw: $(C)$(N)>Broken into pieces lies the old unity of Germany. The imperial crown has lost its luster, the Christian church has split into two hostile camps, and hate and fraternal conflict dictate the course of this unbridled century.$(Z)The rulers of this new era, the kings and princes of the nation-states, rise radiantly, like the Sun King, over the peoples afflicted by poverty and hardship.$(Z)In 1588, England defeats the mighty Spanish Armada. In 1596, the third Spanish state bankruptcy follows. This nearly ruins the famous German banks of the Fuggers and Welsers.$(Z)The Thirty Years' War rages across the fields of Germany, leaving behind chaos of unimaginable proportions. Its end is the destruction and impotence of the German Empire.$(Z)Humanity is seized by deep unrest, seeking new ways to solve the mysteries of existence. Bold and free from the pious ties of the fathers, mankind works inquisitively and speculatively, inventing and discovering. This is the age of war, philosophy, and natural science.$(Z)$(C)And: This is the time of your return, it is the era of$(Z)FUGGER II.$(N)$(N)$(B)

In 1596, the third Spanish state bankruptcy follows. This nearly ruins the famous German banks of the Fuggers and Welsers.$ZThe Thirty Years' War rages across the fields of Germany, leaving behind chaos of unimaginable proportions. Its end is the destruction and impotence of the German Empire.$ZHumanity is seized by deep unrest, seeking new ways to solve the mysteries of existence. Bold and free from the pious ties of the fathers, mankind works inquisitively and speculatively, inventing and discovering. This is the age of war, philosophy, and natural science.$Z$CAnd: This is the time of your return, it is the era of$ZFUGGER II.$N$N$B

  --------

enRaw:
Attention!
--------

You have too little main memory free to play >Die Fugger II<. If you are using an EMS driver, such as EMM386, remove it from the CONFIG.SYS file or change the option RAM XXXX to RAM NOEMS.

You can ignore this warning by pressing 'i'.

enRaw:
Warning!
  --------

  You have too little main memory
  available to play >The Fuggers II<.
  If you are using an EMS driver,
  such as EMM386, remove it from the
  CONFIG.SYS file or change the
  option RAM XXXX to RAM NOEMS.

  You can ignore this warning by
  pressing 'i'.
